importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Mr Vedam was sentenced to a two-and-a-half to five-year term for a drug offense in 1984 as part of a plea agreement, which was served simultaneously with his life sentence for murder.
A deportation order was issued against Mr Vedam in 1988 based on his murder and drug convictions, which remains in effect despite his exoneration of the murder charge.
The article was published on this date, marking the current point in time when Mr Vedam is being detained by ICE pending deportation despite being exonerated of the murder charge.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of Mr Vedam's incarceration began in the 1970s, with his conviction in 1984 and continued imprisonment for over 40 years, culminating in his exoneration in 2025.
In 2024, new evidence emerged that exonerated Mr Vedam of the murder charge, leading to the final closure of the murder case. However, immigration authorities still pursued deportation proceedings.

keyTakeAways: Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam, a legal permanent resident of the United States, spent over 40 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, including 43 years of incarceration.
New evidence has exonerated Mr Vedam of the murder of Tom Kinser, a 19-year-old college student, who went missing in a wooded area with a bullet wound in his skull.
Despite being cleared of murder, Mr Vedam is currently facing deportation to India by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) due to a 1988 deportation order stemming from his prior convictions.
The drug conviction from 1984 remains in effect, and while the murder conviction has been overturned, the immigration order is still being enforced.
Mr Vedam's family and legal team argue that his decades of good behavior, community service, and completion of three degrees should be considered in his immigration case.
The family claims that Mr Vedam has minimal ties to India and that deportation would be a second injustice, as he was already wrongfully imprisoned for over four decades.
ICE did not respond to requests for comment, stating that Mr Vedam remains in custody pending deportation, despite his exoneration.

His sister, Saraswathi Vedam, described the situation as deeply disappointing, noting that he was taken from his family just as he was finally freed and has now been placed in a crowded detention facility with unknown conditions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam, a legal permanent resident of the United States, spent over 40 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, including 43 years of incarceration. After new evidence exonerated him of the murder of Tom Kinser, a college student, and the Centre County District Attorney declined to pursue a new trial, Vedam was finally released from prison. However, he was immediately taken into custody by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and faces deportation to India, where he has no family ties. Despite being cleared of the murder charge, his drug conviction from 1984 remains, and ICE cites a 1988 deportation order as justification for detaining him. His family and legal team argue that his decades of good behavior, community service, and educational achievements should be considered, and that deportation represents a second wrong against a man who has already endured a historic injustice. The case raises concerns about how immigration enforcement agencies respond to individuals who have been exonerated of serious crimes, especially when they have demonstrated rehabilitation and strong ties to the United States.
title: Wrongfully imprisoned for more than 40 years, Pennsylvania man now faces deportation by ICE
